I would be interested in this also. Mainly to determine if by working in closer quarters by putting staff in one centralized location, if their consolidation actually reduces their footprint by reduction of heating and cooling costs, IT infrastructure, Telecommunications equipment, etc.
Have there been studies of this done to determine if consolidation is effective or if it is just a feel good approach?

author: Michael Matthes
text: Has anyone completed an effort to reduce the number of buildings the local government uses to conduct its business?  I'd love to get an case study from a few folks that have done this.  Thanks for any help you can give.
title: Consolidating buildings (reducing local government's footprint)
